abstract.text: Adds one or more items to a keychain.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A dictionary that describes the item to add. A typical
dictionary consists of:
The item’s class.
Different attributes and behaviors apply to different classes of items. You use the
key with a suitable value to tell keychain services whether the data you want to store represents a password, a certificate, a cryptographic key, or something else. See
The data.
Use the
key to indicate the data you want to store. Keychain services takes care of encrypting this data if the item is secret, namely when it’s one of the password types or involves a private key.
Optional attributes.

Include attribute keys that help you find the item later, indicate how your app uses the data, and how the system shares the data. You can add any number of attributes, although many are specific to a particular class of item. For the attributes applicable to the keychain item you add, see the entry for the item’s class in
Optional return types.
Include return type keys to indicate what data, if any, you want returned upon successful completion. You often ignore the return data from a
call, in which case you don’t need to include any return result key. See
for more information.
On return, a reference to the newly added items. The exact type of the result is based on the values supplied in
, as discussed in
. Pass
if you don’t need the result. Otherwise, your app becomes responsible for releasing the referenced object.
A result code. See
To add multiple items to a keychain at once use the
key in the
dictionary with an array of dictionaries (each corresponding to one of the items) as its value. This is only supported for non-password items.
When you use Xcode to create an application, Xcode adds an

entitlement to the application bundle. Keychain Services uses this entitlement to grant the application access to its own keychain items. To share the new keychain item to among multiple apps, include the
key in the
dictionary. The value of this key must be the name of a keychain access group to which all the programs that share this item belong.
blocks the calling thread, so it can cause your app’s UI to hang if called from the main thread. Instead, call
from a background dispatch queue or
function:

code: func addKeychainItem(attributes attrs: CFDictionary, _ completion: @escaping (OSStatus, CFTypeRef?) -> Void) {

abstract.text: Secure the data your app manages, and control access to your app.
Adds one or more items to a keychain.
Add network credentials to the keychain on behalf of the user.

doc://com.apple.security/documentation/S.title: Adding a password to the keychain

abstract.text: Specify the class of a keychain item.
Specify how you want returned keychain item data formatted.
A key with a value that’s a string indicating the access group the item is in.
A dictionary key whose value is the item’s class.
A key whose value is an array of items to search.
A key whose value is the item’s data.
Evaluate result codes common to many Security framework functions.
Enable apps to share keychain items with each other by adding the apps to an access group.

doc://com.apple.security/documentation/S.title: Sharing access to keychain items among a collection of apps

abstract.text: Store a certificate in the keychain for safekeeping.

doc://com.apple.security/documentation/S.title: Storing a Certificate in the Keychain

abstract.text: Store and access cryptographic keys in the keychain.
Modify items in the keychain when the user’s data changes.
A reference to an immutable dictionary object.
An untyped "generic" reference to any Core Foundation object.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
